Award.AwardTitle: Role of Motor/cargo Attachment Mechanics in Collective Kinesin Transport

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cell survival depends on the efficient transport and sorting of protein and chemical species into different functional compartments. Nanoscale motor proteins that grasp membrane-bound cargos and move them along polymer filaments enable this transport. The resultant cargo motion is thought to arise from the cooperative action of multiple motor proteins, but the extent of cooperation and the molecular mechanisms that enable it are poorly understood. One possible mechanism for cooperation lies in the ability of multiple motors to share the load necessary to move the cargo. Such load splitting is expected to depend strongly on the mechanical properties of the cargo surface, but the detailed relationship between load splitting, transport efficiency, and cargo mechanics is unknown. The objective of this research project is to determine how membrane mechanics influences the ability of motor proteins to cooperatively transport cargos. To this end, biomimetic cargos with well-controlled interfacial chemistry and mechanical properties will be generated and coupled to motor proteins in vitro. The mechanical properties of the cargo surfaces will be varied from purely rigid surfaces with immobile motor attachment sites to purely fluid surfaces made of lipids that can rearrange their positions. The fluid cargos, which are thought to better mimic the properties of cargos in living cells, would allow motor binding sites to easily move on the cargo surface as the motor proteins move. The impact of these interfacial lipid rearrangements on cargo motion will be assessed using precision biophysical tools. Specifically, the ability of motors to cooperatively move fluid and rigid cargos against an external force will be determined and quantitatively compared. Computer simulations and analytical theory will be developed to understand the experimental data and generate testable predictions for the effects of membrane mechanics on cargo transport in cells.

If successful, this research will provide important new insight into the fundamental mechanisms and regulation of intracellular transport, while creating outreach and training activities at the interface of biology, physics, and engineering. In particular, community college and undergraduate students will participate in hands-on research, and this work will form the thesis project of one graduate student, who will develop expertise in experiments, computation and analytical theory. The outcomes of this project will be incorporated into interdisciplinary biophysics/biomechanics courses at UCSB and the Santa Barbara Advanced School for Quantitative Biology, and will be disseminated broadly in publications and conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the molecular machinery that cells use to transport proteins and chemicals into different functional compartments. This transport is enabled by nanoscale motor proteins that grasp membrane-bound cargos and move them along polymer filaments. The resultant cargo motion depends upon the cooperative action of multiple motor proteins that work in concert, yet few experimental methods allow for detailed investigation of these mechanisms. In this project, we developed new experimental techniques that allow the ability of multiple motors to cooperate and share load to be investigated. Such load splitting is believed to improve the efficiency of cargo transport in cells, while also allowing for regulation of cargo motion.

In order to determine how load splitting is influenced by the mechanical properties of the cargo surface, we developed and characterized a robust and versatile biomimetic cargo system that allows for control of the cargo size, composition, and interfacial mechanics through use of lipid-stabilized oil-in-water emulsion droplets. The droplets can be fluorescently labeled to enable visualization with high-resolution optical microscopy, and can be manipulated in three-dimensions using a laser-based technique called optical tweezers. Optical tweezers have been used extensively to study the ability of motor proteins to move rigid cargos, such as plastic microparticles. Under this award, we extended this technique to allow for the precise manipulation and tracking of oil droplets under conditions of high force loading, where we expected to see the greatest effects of motor cooperativity. We also developed new computer simulations to investigate the effects of load sharing and protein-protein interactions on cargo transport in cells.

This award supported the training of one graduate student, one postdoctoral scholar, and two undergraduate students, who all developed skills in optics, instrument design, fluorescence microscopy, recombinant protein expression and purification, biochemical analysis, computer simulations, image processing, software development, scientific communication, laboratory safety and ethics. Additionally, the graduate student  and postdoctoral scholar were trained in project management and leadership.

This work resulted in two scientific publications and six presentations at national scientific conferences, and the results of this award were incorporated into undergraduate- and graduate-level courses. Presentations were also made to California community college students, and to TechTrek an experiential summer camp sponsored by the American Association of University Women (AAUW) that is designed to make science and engineering accessible, exciting and fun for middle school girls.
